title-group.article-title: Analytical solution for the dynamic analysis of a delaminated composite beam traversed by a moving constant force

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad H Kargarnovin, School of Mechanical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, 14588-89694, Tehran, Iran Email: mhkargar@sharif.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A closed form solution is presented in this paper to study the dynamics of a composite beam with a single delamination under the action of a moving constant force. The delaminated beam is divided into four interconnected beams using the delamination limits as their boundaries. Governing motion equations are derived in which the differential stretching and the bending-extension coupling are considered. The method of modal analysis is adopted to derive analytically the dynamic response of each beam. The obtained results for the free vibrations of delaminated beam are verified against reported similar results in the literature. Moreover, the maximum dynamic response of such a beam is compared with a healthy beam. The effects of different parameters such as the force velocity, different ply configuration and the size, depth and spanwise location of the single delamination on the dynamic response of the beam are studied. It is noticed that the presence of delamination has significant influence on the dynamic response of the beam.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The use of fiber-reinforced composite laminates are common in the construction of aerospace, civil, marine, automotive and other high performance structures. However, composites are prone to damage. Among various types of damage modes that are likely to occur in laminated composites, delamination is probably the most frequently occurring type of damage. The occurrence of delamination changes the global dynamic characteristics of any structure specifically the natural frequencies, mode shapes and dynamic response of such structures. In-depth understanding of this phenomenon currently has attracted the attention of many researchers in the field of aerospace, mechanical and civil engineering. Dynamic analysis of a healthy beam due to a moving force has received a good amount of attention in the literature, whereas dynamic analysis of the delaminated beam under the action of moving force has not yet been approached.

The finite element dynamic response of an unsymmetric laminated composite beam subjected to moving loads has been studied by Kadivar and Mohebpour (1998). Abu-hilal and Mohsen (2000) analyzed vibrational behavior of elastic homogeneous isotropic beams with general boundary conditions due to a moving harmonic force. An investigation into the dynamics of vehicle–occupant–structure-induced vibration of bridges traversed by moving vehicles was presented by Esmailzadeh and Jalili (2003). Kargarnovin and Younesian (2004) studied the response of a Timoshenko beam with uniform cross-section and infinite length supported by a generalized Pasternak-type viscoelastic foundation subjected to an arbitrary-distributed harmonic moving load. Dynamic behavior of a laminated composite beam (LCB) supported by a generalized Pasternak type viscoelastic foundation subjected to a moving two degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) oscillator with a constant traveling velocity was studied by Ahmadian et al. (2008a,b). Dehestani et al. (2009) presented an analytical-numerical method to determine the dynamic response of Euler-Bernoulli beams with various boundary conditions under a moving object. The dynamic response of a free–free flexible beam floating in an unbounded water domain under the effect of moving loads was numerically analyzed by Qiu (2009).

On the other hand, there has been growing interest in studying the free vibration of delaminated beams. Wang et al. (1982) have studied the free vibrations of an isotropic beam with a through-width delamination by using four Euler–Bernoulli beams connected at the delamination boundaries. It was found that for beams with a short and close to midplane delamination, the results for the natural frequencies were close to the experimental results. However, according to this study, dramatic interpenetration of the delaminated sublaminates is seen that is physically impossible in the case of off-midplane delaminations. This is because the delaminated layers were assumed to deform ‘freely’ without touching each other (known as free mode) and thus have different transverse deformation. To avoid this kind of incompatibility, Mujumdar and Suryanarayan (1988) proposed a model based on the assumption that the delaminated layers are constrained to have identical transverse deformations. This was called the constrained mode in contrast with the free mode proposed by Wang et al. (1982). A similar constrained mode approach was used by Tracy and Pardoen (1989) on a simply supported composite beam, Hu and Hwu (1995) on a sandwich beam, and Shu and Fan (1996) on a bimaterial beam.

Luo and Hanagud (2000) proposed a model based on the Timoshenko beam theory, which uses piecewise-linear springs to simulate the ‘open’ and ‘closed’ behaviors between the delaminated surfaces in the free vibration study. The spring stiffness would then be equal to zero (0) for the free mode and infinity (∞) for the constrained mode. Shu and Della have presented an analytical solution for the free vibration of composite beams with two non-overlapping (Shu and Della, 2004) and overlapping (Della and Shu, 2005) delaminations using free and constrained modes. Free vibration analysis of laminated beams with a single delamination has been presented by Ramtekkar (2009).

The review of the all above-mentioned published papers on the dynamic behavior of delaminated beams reveals that their study is restricted only to free vibration analysis. To the authors’ best knowledge; there is not even a single investigation in the literature on the dynamic response of the delaminated beam due to a moving force. Thus, the main contribution of the present work is to analyze the dynamic behavior of the delaminated beam under the action of moving force. Classical beam theory is used and beam's internal damping is neglected. It should be pointed out that though the analytical solution presented in this paper is suitable for a single delamination, nonetheless the presented methodology can be extended for the beams with multiple delaminations as well.

sec.title: 2.1. Geometry
sec.p:
First there is a delaminated composite beam–moving constant force system as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Delaminated composite beam traversed by a moving force.

The beam is supported by movable simply supported ends, has the length of L, and rectangular cross-section of b × h. There is an embedded delamination at the depth of h2 from the upper edge with length of Ld located at L1 with respect to the left support. In order to analyze the dynamic of such beam, classical beam theory is employed. Furthermore, it is assumed that the force is moving at a constant velocity v along the axial direction of the beam from the left end to the right. In addition, ξ(t) denotes the location of the moving force at time t.

As it can be seen from Figure 2, the beam can be modeled as a combination of four sub-beams connected at the delamination boundaries x=L1 and x=L1+Ld. In this way there will be four sub-beams of one to four with lengths and thicknesses of Li × hi (i = 1 to 4) where L2 = L3 = Ld, L4 = L − L1 − L2, h1 = h4 = h and h3 = h − h2, respectively. mi,Di and Ai (i = 1 to 4) are denoted as the mass density per unit length, reduced bending stiffness and cross sectional area of four sub-beams, respectively. Figure 2.
Representation of beam with delamination into four sub-beams.

sec.title: 2.2. Assumption and equations of motion
sec.p: In the present study, it is assumed that the delaminated surface between the sub-beams of two and three are assumed to move together, i.e. no gap will be produced during the beam transverse motion (constraint mode) (Mujumdar and Suryanarayan, 1988; Tracy and Pardoen, 1989; Hu and Hwu, 1995; Shu and Fan, 1996; Ramtekkar, 2009). Based on this assumption, the equation of motion for each of the sub-beams one and four is (Meirovitch, 1980): (1)Di∂4wi∂x4+mi∂2wi∂t2=-f(x,t) (i=1and4) and for the sub-beams of two and three is (Meirovitch, 1980; Mujumdar and Suryanarayan, 1988; Shu and Della, 2004; Della and Shu, 2005): (2)(D2+D3)∂4w2∂x4+(m2+m3)∂2w2∂t2=-f(x,t) in which w is the beam's deflection.

In a composite beam, when bending-extension is coupled, the material reduced bending stiffness constants are given as (Shu and Della, 2004): (3)Di=D11(i)-(B11(i))2A11(i). (i=1,2,3,4) where A11(i), B11(i) and D11(i) are extensional, coupling and the bending stiffnesses defined as (Jones, 1999): A11(i)=b∑k=1ni(Q¯11k)k(zk-zk-1),B11(i)=b2∑k=1ni(Q¯11k)k(zk2-zk-12),D11(i)=b3∑k=1ni(Q¯11k)k(zk3-zk-13),Q¯11k=Q11kcos4ϕ+Q22ksin4ϕ+2(Q12k+2Q66k)cos2ϕsin2ϕ where ni is the number of plies and Qij are as follows (Jones, 1999): Q11=E111-υ12υ21, Q22=E221-υ12υ21,Q66=G12, Q12=υ12Q22, υ21=υ12E22E11
It should be noted that the ϕ is the angle of the kth lamina orientation and zk and zk-1 are the distance of the kth lamina with respect to the midplane surface.

Moreover, E11,E22,G12,ν12andν21 are the longitudinal and transverse Young’s modulus, in-plane shear modulus, longitudinal and transverse Poisson’s ratio, respectively. Note that, the second term on the right hand side of equation (3) represents the reduction of stiffness due to the bending–extension coupling (Shu and Della, 2004).

sec.title: 3. Method of solution
sec.p: In order to use modal analysis in solving governing differential equations given in equations (1) and (2), primarily eigenvalues (natural frequencies) must be obtained and then their corresponding eigenfunctions (mode shapes). To follow the above procedures, in the following sections, first the free vibration is directly analyzed and then work takes place on calculating the dynamic response of the beam.

sec.title: 3.1. Free vibration analysis
sec.p:
The governing equations for the free vibrations of the problem under consideration are obtained by letting the forcing term (fi(x,t)) in equations (1) and (2), to be zero i.e.: (4)Di∂4wi∂x4+mi∂2wi∂t2=0 (i=1and4)
(5)(D2+D3)∂4w2∂x4+(m2+m3)∂2w2∂t2=0

For free vibrations the following answer is assumed to the above relations (Meirovitch, 1980): (6)wi(x,t)=Wi(x)sin(ωt) (i=1,2and4) in which ω is the beam's natural frequency and Wi(x) is the mode shape of the ith sub-beam.

Substituting equation (6) in equations (4) and (5) and eliminating the trivial solution sin(ωt)=0, the generalized solutions can be obtained for the differential equations as (Meirovitch, 1980): (7)Wi(x)=Cicos(λixL)+Sisin(λixL)+CHicosh(λixL) +SHisinh(λixL) where: (8)λi4=ω2miDiL4,(i=1and4), λ24=ω2(m2+m3)(D2+D3)L4 the 12 unknown coefficients including Ci, Si, CHi and SHi (i = 1, 2 and 4) are determined by four boundary conditions and eight continuity conditions. The appropriate boundary conditions at x=0 for the sub-beam 1 and x=L for the sub-beam 4 shown at Figure 1 are as follows: if the boundary is simply supported: Wi=0 and W″i=0, if the support is clamped: Wi=0 and W'i=0, and if it is free: W″i=0 and W″'i=0. Note that, the notation of prime (′) above W denotes differentiation with respect to the x-coordinate. In addition, for the sub-beam two (see Figure 3), following conditions have to be considered, i.e.: the continuity conditions for the deflection and slope, equilibrium conditions for the shear and the bending moments at x=L1 represented respectively, as follows: (9)W1=W2, W'1=W'2
(10)V1=V2+V3
(11)M1=M2+M3-P2(h12-h22)+P3(h12-h32) in which: (12)Vi=-DiW″'i
(13)Mi=-DiW″i, (i=1,2,3,4)
Figure 3.
Equilibrium condition for the shear forces and bending moments between sub-beam one and sub-beams two and three at x=L1.

Furthermore, the axial forces Pi can be obtained from the condition of stretching/shortening compatibility between the delaminated sub-beams and axial equilibrium (Mujumdar and Suryanarayan, 1988), therefore: (14)P3LdA11(3)-P2LdA11(2)=h12[W'1(L1)-W'4(L1+Ld)]
(15)P1=P2+P3=0
The combination of equations (11), (14) and (15) yields: (16)⇒D1W″1(L1)=(D2+D3)W″2(L1) -h124Ld[W'1(L1)-W'4(L1+Ld)]1A11(2)+1A11(3)
Note that the continuity conditions for the deflection and slope, equilibrium conditions for the shear and the bending moments at x=L1+Ld can be derived in a similar way as described above.

sec.title: 3.2. Beam's dynamic response
sec.p: In order to find the dynamic response of the beam under consideration the beam's eigenvalues and eigenfunctions are used, obtained in the free vibration analysis in series expansion form as follows (Meirovitch, 1980): (17)wi(x,t)=∑k=1nWik(x)qk(t), (i=1,2,4) in which the qk(t) are unknown time coefficients to be calculated, n is the total number of the considered terms and Wik(x) represent the kth normalized mode shapes related to the ith sub-beam. Substituting equation (17) into equations (1) and (2), multiplying by sides by Wij(x), (i=1,2,4;j=1,2,…,n) and integrating over each sub-beam length, one yields to: (18)∫0L1∑k=1n[m1W1kq··k(t)+D1W″1kqk(t)]W1jdx +∫L1L1+Ld∑k=1n[m1W2kq··k(t)+(D2+D3)W″2kqk(t)]W2jdx+∫L1+LdL∑k=1n[m1W4kq··k(t)+D1W″4kqk(t)]W4jdx=∫0L1(-f0)δ(x-vt)W1jdx+∫L1L1+Ld(-f0)δ(x-vt)W2jdx+∫L1+LdL(-f0)δ(x-vt)W4jdx

Making use of the orthogonality relationship of the normalized mode shapes, equation (18) becomes: (19)q··k+ωk2qk=Fk(t), k=1,2,…,n where: (20)Fk(t)=1Mk{-f0W1k(vt)t≤L1vfor sub-beam1-f0W2k(vt)L1v<t≤L1+Ldvfor sub-beam2-f0W4k(vt)L1+Ldv<t≤Lvfor sub-beam4 in which: (21)Mk=m1[∫0L1W1k2dx+∫L1L1+LdW2k2dx+∫L1+LdLW4k2dx]

If before the concentrated force starts to enter from the left end of the beam, the beam is initially at rest, i.e. with zero initial displacement and velocity, then by imposing these initial conditions on equation (19) the following is obtained: (22)qk(t)=1ωk∫0tsinωk(t-τ)Fk(τ)dτorqk(t)=-f0Mkωk{∫0tsinωk(t-τ)W1k(vτ)dτt≤L1v∫0L1vsinωk(t-τ)W1k(vτ)dτ+∫L1vtsinωk(t-τ)W2k(vτ)dτL1v<t≤L1+Ldv∫0L1vsinωk(t-τ)W1k(vτ)dτ+∫L1vL1+Ldvsinωk(t-τ)W2k(vτ)dτ+∫L1+Ldvtsinωk(t-τ)W4k(vτ)dτL1+Ldv<t≤Lv

The forced responses of delaminated beams can then be determined by substituting qk(t) from equation (22) into equation (17). It should be pointed out that though the above analytical solution method is applicable for a beam with a single delamination; nevertheless it can be suitably applied for beams with multiple delaminations as well.

sec.title: 4. Numerical results and discussions
sec.p: In the following sections there the obtained results are first discussed, and then study takes place on the beam's delamination phenomenon under the action of constant moving force.

sec.title: 4.1. Verification
sec.p: To validate the accuracy of the authors’ developed computer program, the obtained results from this code for the free vibration of a cantilever composite beam with a single delamination were compared with those of Shen and Grady (1992) (experimental and analytical analysis), Hu and Hwu (1995) (finite element analysis), and Luo and Hanagud (2000) (analytical results). The beam is made of T300/934 graphite/epoxy beam with a [0/90]2s stacking sequence. The material properties for the lamina are (Shen and Grady, 1992): E11=134GPa,E22=10.3GPa,G12=5GPa,υ12=0.33,ρ=1480kg/m3

It should be noted that the considered single delamination is located at the beam's midspan (central delamination). Moreover, for the considered eight-ply beam, the single delamination can be positioned at interface one, two, three or four (see Figure 4, in which only one case is shown) one at a time. Figure 4.
Interface locations of the delaminations for a [0/90]2s graphite/epoxy composite laminate.

The problem for considered geometry is solved for four different position of delamination and for brevity the results of fundamental frequencies are shown for two cases in Tables 1 and 2 along with other similar published data. Good agreements are seen between the frequencies predicted by our self-developed computer program for this model and the experimental, analytical and numerical results reported by others. It should be further noted that the listed data in this table are for two different types of bending-extension couplings. Table 1.
Fundamental frequencies (Hz) of the beam with single delamination located at interface one
Delamination length Presenta Presentb Shen and Grady (1992) Luo and Hanagud (2000) Hu and Hwu (1995)
Exp. 1 Exp. 2 Exp. 3 Cons. Cons. Free Cons. Free
Intact 81.88 81.88 79.88 79.88 79.75 82.04 81.86 81.86 81.87 81.87
25.4 mm 80.72 80.47 78.38 79.13 77.00 80.13 81.84 81.84
50.8 mm 76.36 75.36 74.38 75.00 76.75 75.29 76.81 76.81 76.52 76.52
76.2 mm 68.17 66.14 68.25 66.25 66.38 66.94 67.64 67.64
101.6 mm 58.35 55.67 57.62 57.50 57.50 57.24 56.95 56.95 56.56 56.56

without bending-extension coupling. b

Table 2.
Fundamental frequencies (Hz) of the beam with single delamination located at interface two
Delamination length Presenta Presentb Shen and Grady (1992) Luo and Hanagud (2000) Hu and Hwu (1995)
Exp. 1 Exp. 2 Exp. 3 Cons. Cons. Free Cons. Free
Intact 81.88 81.88 79.88 79.88 79.75 82.04 81.86 81.86 81.87 81.87
25.4 mm 81.00 80.58 78.38 78.38 76.63 81.39 80.86 80.86 - -

without bending-extension coupling. b
with bending-extension coupling.

From close inspection of obtained results, it has been noticed that there exist good agreements between the authors’ results compared to other reported similar ones. Out of this comparison assurance was given that the developed program is working properly, hence in the next section analysis is further pursued on the dynamic behavior of such problems.

sec.title: 4.2. Delaminated beam under the action of moving constant force
sec.p: In order to investigate the effect of different delamination parameters on the dynamic response of the beam; the developed code for the dynamic analysis of such a beam is capable of accepting different parameters related to delamination namely; its location from top surface, length and spanwise location. Unless mentioned otherwise, the beam with simply supported boundary conditions has been considered.

To see the effect of different parameters on the dynamic response of the beam this code has been run and the outcome of such changes are depicted in Figures 5 to 7. As illustrated in these figures, the variation of the dynamic magnification factor (DMF) vs. (Tfτ) and w¯m vs. x¯f for different delamination parameters are depicted. It should be noted that the DMF represents the ratio of the maximum magnitude of the dynamic deflection at the midpoint of the beam to the deflection of corresponding point under static loading. The symbol Tf denotes the fundamental period of the healthy beam and τ represents the travel time of the moving force from the left end of the beam to the right end (τ=Lv). Moreover, w¯m indicates the dynamic deflection at the midspan of the beam and x¯f is the non-dimensional time i.e.(tτ) or force non-dimensional horizontal position (vtL). It should be emphasized that though the obtained results are for the simply supported beam nevertheless, this could be extended with no difficulties to the other types of boundary conditions. Moreover, in the presented numerical results, the dynamic responses variation converge to the value of 0.1% when the first ten modes of assumed eigenfunctions are taken into consideration. In this analysis the following information have been used: the midspan static deflection of the beam under a central force of f0 is f0L348D1, the stacking sequence is the same as shown in Figure 4 and the beam geometric dimensions are taken to be as: L=10m,b=50cm,h=5cm
Figure 5.
a) Variation of DMF vs. Tfτ for different vertical location of delamination b) Variation of w¯m vs. x¯f for different vertical location of delamination.
(L¯1=0.3,L¯d=0.4).
Moreover the following non-dimensional variables L¯1,L¯d for the spanwise location and length of delamination, respectively: L¯1=L1L,L¯d=LdL

A close inspection of results for DMF on Figures 5 to 7 reveals that this parameter for the delaminated beam is always larger than the corresponding value of the healthy beam at force critical velocity. Noting that the force critical velocity is the velocity in which the maximum DMF occurs. In addition, it can be said that the variation of DMF of the healthy and delaminated beams can be basically divided into two distinct regions, namely, the “under critical” and the “over critical” regions. In the “under critical” region the values of DMF both increases and decreases as Tfτ increases. In order to discuss the trend of variation for DMF in detail, these changes are first reviewed for the healthy beam then this variation is scrutinized for the delaminated beam.

sec.title: 4.2.1. i- Healthy beam
sec.p: The DMF increases up to Tfτ=0.3 and then reaches to a minimum value at Tfτ=0.4. As Tfτ increases further, the maximum value of DMF occurs at Tfτ=1.2. This is fully in accordance with other reported result in the other literature for example: for the moving constant force problem (Kadivar and Mohebpour, 1998) and moving oscillatory mass (Ahmadian et al., 2008a). Figure 5(b) illustrates the time history of w¯m corresponding to the critical velocity related to the Figure 5(a). It is shown that the maximum deflection at the beam center occurs when the moving force passes the position of 0.75 of the beam length.

sec.title: 4.2.2. ii- Delaminated beam
sec.p: Figure 5(a) shows the variation of DMF versus Tfτ for different vertical location of delamination.

It is further noticed that the peak value of curves for the delaminated beam is reached at lower velocity with respect to the healthy beam. Besides, when the delamination is located at the interfaces one and two (see Figure 4) the maximum DMF occurs at Tfτ=1.12 but if the delamination is located at the interfaces three and four the maximum DMF takes place at Tfτ=1.15. It is shown in Figure 5(b) that the maximum deflection at the beam center occurs when the moving force passes the position of 0.75 when the delamination located at the interface three or four and at 0.78 of the beam length when the delamination located at the interface one or two.

Figure 6(a) displays the effect of delamination length on the beam response. It is shown that for the delamination length L¯d=0.2 and 0.4, the maximum DMF occurs at Tfτ=1.1, while for the delamination length of L¯d=0.6, this maximum occurs at Tfτ=0.84. This means that increase of the delamination length more that half of the beam's length causes significant effect on the critical force velocity. Figure 6(b) shows the time history of w¯m at the critical velocity related to the Figure 6(a). As it is seen from this figure, the maximum deflection at the beam center occurs when the moving force reaches the values of 0.74 of the beam length when the delamination length is L¯d=0.2, 0.77 of the beam length when the delamination length is L¯d=0.4 and 0.68 of the beam length when the delamination length is L¯d=0.6. Figure 6.
a) Variation of DMF vs. Tfτ for different delamination length b) Variation of w¯m vs. x¯f for different delamination length (L¯1=0.3,interface1).
Figure 7.
a) Variation of DMF vs. Tfτ for different delamination spanwise location b) Variation of w¯m vs. x¯f for different delamination spanwise location (L¯d=0.4,interface1).

The influence of delamination spanwise location on the beam’s dynamic response is depicted in Figure 7(a). As it is seen from this figure, the maximum DMF occurs at the same value of Tfτ=0.96 for the parameter L¯1=1 and 2, while this maximum occurs at Tfτ=1.12 for delamination spanwise parameter L¯1=3. Referred to Figure 7(b) for L¯1=1,2and3 the DMF occurs at critical speed when the moving force has traveled 0.72, 0.68 and 0.78 of the beam length, respectively.

A brief survey of the effect of delamination parameters on the critical velocity of the delaminated beam is presented in Tables 3 to 5. Table 3.

As it can be seen from presented results in Tables 3 to 5, the boundary condition has a significant effect on the beam dynamic response and more specifically on the load critical velocity.

The influence of lay-up configuration on the delaminated beam response is illustrated in Figure 8. A close inspection of this figure reveals that the symmetric configuration has softening effect and therefore, has a higher dynamic deflection than the unsymmetric configuration. Figure 8.
Effect of lay-up configuration on the dynamic magnification factor variation vs. Tfτ (L¯1=0.3,L¯d=0.4,interface1).

Figure 9 displays the effect of bending-extension coupling on the dynamic response of the delaminated beam. As it is seen in this figure, neglecting the bending-extension coupling decreases the DMF of the beam at any velocity or (Tfτ). Moreover, for both cases the maximum DMF occurs at Tfτ=1.08 no matter of coupling effect. Figure 9.
Effect of the coupling term on the dynamic magnification factor with respect to Tfτ (L¯1=0.3,L¯d=0.4,interface1).

Consider a delaminated cantilevered composite beam subjected to a concentrated transverse harmonic force at the free end of the beam. The results of the normalized dynamic deflection, bending moment and shear force at x = L1 are shown in Figures 10 to 12, respectively. Figure 10.
Dynamic deflection versus time at the delamination boundary x = L1..
Figure 11.
Dynamic bending moment versus time at the delamination boundary x = L1. ---- sub-beam 2, - - - - sub-beam 3. Figure 12.
Dynamic shear force versus time at the delamination boundary x = L1. ---- sub-beam 2, - - - - sub-beam 3.
These parameters have been normalized with respect to the corresponding static values.

The dimensionless delamination length is 0.6, and the central delamination is located at the interface one (see Figure 4). The concentrated transverse harmonic force is chosen as: f(x,t)=f0sin(2πft)δ(x-L) in which f0 = 0.5 N, and f = 0.5 Hz, 5 Hz, 6 Hz and 8 Hz one at the time.

The dynamic response of the delaminated beam is greatly dependent on the frequency of the exciting force. As expected, the closer the exciting frequency is to the natural frequencies of the delaminated beams (0.5164 Hz and 5.9671 Hz), the greater the dynamic response amplitude is.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p:
The current work presents an analytical solution to the dynamic behavior of delaminated composite beam under the moving constant force by decomposing the beam into four interconnected classical beams with the delamination limits as their boundaries. A thorough study is carried out to investigate the effects of the force velocity and delamination parameters on the beam deflection at the midspan of the beam to provide data of practical engineering relevance for analyzing the structural damage sensitivity under a moving force. Numerical results are presented in the present paper for a simply supported beam with a force travelling with various prescribed constant speed. The outcomes of this study are as follows:
The dynamic deflection is sensitive to the depth, length and spanwise location of the delamination.
The existence of single delamination alters the value of the critical velocity of the traveling force.
The existence of single delamination alters the location of the force when DMF occurs.
The symmetric configuration of laminae has softening effect and therefore, has a higher dynamic deflection than the unsymmetric configuration.
Neglecting the bending-extension coupling in a delaminated beam decreases the DMF of the beam at any velocity.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
